I used to specialize in WiFi and the entire idea of making your primary connection over 6 is insane. People are going to by this is places like NYC where the RF spectrum is constantly screaming and will get awful performance.
Oh! Hey lexi!

to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.
@TheLexikitty oh hey! nice to see you around :)
RIGHT!!! It’s crazy to me, and they could’ve done this TV over some sort of Ethernet and maybe even POE+++ if it’s efficient enough

Why would 6ghz be worse for RF interference? Is there something else using that range in the USA or something? Here in the UK it's much easier to find clear channels in 6ghz. Majority of people will use the ISP supplied router which wont be Wi-Fi 6e or 7 capable. We recently tested 6ghz in a large city and we couldn't see any other 6ghz radios except our own broadcasting.

As an owner of 3 Frame TVs (Non-Pro's from 2020 and 2022) due to the desire of "TVs that don't look like TVs". Everything Quinn said in this is true. Can't relate to the wireless portion since the Non-Pros use a cable to connect the box to the TV, but the Samsung software is atrocious, and is still not fixed. The "art mode" is NEVER consistent in turning on or off correctly after turning off connected devices. Software is dog-slow and Samsung is adamant on trying to make sure you pay for their art subscription for features that should be STANDARD on a TV focused on letting you display art at a premium price tag. The mounting method changed in 2022 I think? the original mount was at least long enough to get one screw onto a stud, but the new mount sucks. If I were to say anything positive, it's that it can be confused for art sometimes, and it definitely makes a room feel a little nicer. Idk if I'd ever pay for the "Pro" version though. The regular frames were already too expensive for what they are, and I feel like we'd all less harsh on these TVs if the price matched the frustration but it doesn't.

Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.

I used to specialize in WiFi and the entire idea of making your primary connection over 6 is insane. People are going to by this is places like NYC where the RF spectrum is constantly screaming and will get awful performance.
Oh! Hey lexi!

to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.
@TheLexikitty oh hey! nice to see you around :)
RIGHT!!! It’s crazy to me, and they could’ve done this TV over some sort of Ethernet and maybe even POE+++ if it’s efficient enough

Why would 6ghz be worse for RF interference? Is there something else using that range in the USA or something? Here in the UK it's much easier to find clear channels in 6ghz. Majority of people will use the ISP supplied router which wont be Wi-Fi 6e or 7 capable. We recently tested 6ghz in a large city and we couldn't see any other 6ghz radios except our own broadcasting.

Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.

I used to specialize in WiFi and the entire idea of making your primary connection over 6 is insane. People are going to by this is places like NYC where the RF spectrum is constantly screaming and will get awful performance.
Oh! Hey lexi!

to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.
@TheLexikitty oh hey! nice to see you around :)

As an owner of 3 Frame TVs (Non-Pro's from 2020 and 2022) due to the desire of "TVs that don't look like TVs". Everything Quinn said in this is true. The mounting method changed in 2022 I think? the original mount was at least long enough to get one screw onto a stud, but the new mount sucks. If I were to say anything positive, it's that it can be confused for art sometimes, and it definitely makes a room feel a little nicer. Idk if I'd ever pay for the "Pro" version though. KG, recently bought A95L 65” due to sale price over Bravia 8ii. Now Bravia 8ii price dropped is it worth exchanging A95L within return period for Bravia 8ii? Streaming & Blu ray sdr and hdr use mostly.
Thanks 😊

Not every OLED is the same, especially considering the cheaper Samsung 84 models that are on sale. It’s important to know these TVs are great if you’re in a very dark room, but if you’re planning on putting one of these cheaper OLED in a bright family room I would strongly recommend not buying this..

Like I stated in the video you'll want to pay up for the QD-OLEDs or enhanced OLEDs if your room is bright, but for the most part I think OLED of any class should be bright enough for most rooms there are definitely cases where your room can be too bright for one of these entry level TVs but your going to have to really have a TV that is positioned opposite a window in that type of bright room scenario in this case.

I would like your opinion on the Samsung S90F 42 vs the LG C5 42. I know in the larger sizes it QD-OLED vs W but in the 42 it WOLED vs WOLED. My question is which is better  to use as a work monitor with some use as TV for movie night.  Thanks!

For a work monitor I would say they are both pretty equal. I actually have the S90D 42 inch and I came from a 48” C1 I noticed less aggressive ASBL (dimming w/ static elements) on the Samsung but I don’t know if that’s improved on the c5 too i imagine it did. The C5 may be a little better than the S90F 42” brightness wise from what I’ve heard. Thank you for your support btw definitely means a lot!
I already got the TV just needed to get some movies so I hit up the Criterion sale at Barnes &Noble.

Great content, very  helpful, and we are trying to  decide between the Samsung  65" S84F or  Samsung - 55” Class S90F.  Therefore, are these models considered to be premium  (mid-range) OR more-so entry level models?  It appears,  'The Samsung S84F OLED TV sits at the very bottom of Samsung's OLED lineup, which maybe okay for many.
S84F is an entry level OLED using a basic WOLED panel, S90F utilizes a QD-OLED which have higher brightness and better color capabilities.

You're right these mini LEDs are over priced I was looking a few weeks ago and I swear the 75" TCL and Hisense Qm8 and u8 were like $1000 $1200 at most now they're up to 1400. Like you said might as well get the budget oled at that same price
I’m going to buy. A 85 inch for the living room. Do u have a preferred Hisense or tcl tv? I like those brands because they are in my budget like 2k

I bought a 65” a95l when priced dropped to complete warranty replacement on older a8h. Now that Bravia 8ii is priced lower should I exchange a95l for Bravia 8ii?
Both seem to have benefits over each. Have few weeks to decide on a95l.
Yes you should get the newer brighter tv

@jrmcdonald821
Thanks! a95l cost me $50 difference and B8ii was $1300 difference.
Took a95l to meet warranty deadline & think about it.
Bravia 8ii price more pleasing now.
A95l seems too bright some areas not all. A95l pro sdr quality. Not over highlighting details. B8ii pros AI scene recognition to make actors more life like. Brighter daytime & hdr. More closer to reference. Better detail highlights more pleasing even if not as accurate? I’m no expert.
Both nice TV’s. Think Bravia 8 ii better choice don’t want to make poor choice with final decision.

Wait do you get to swap it like your under the terms still or would you paying full price. Theres not a super large difference between the two aside from a bit more brightness, but in most content you would hardly notice it

@TechWithKG I can swap a95l for B8ii by paying $300 difference. I have 8 days left on return period. I was all set to purchase B8ii for $3200 but A95l dropped to $1998 around warranty exchange deadline costing $200 on top what they were giving me back.
I ended up liking the A95L making it harder to decide if better to return for Bravia 8 ii.
@Cinemafan-t5u Really depends on if the extra brightness is worth the extra $300 to you they are very similar TVs otherwise.

I want an OLED under 55 inches for gaming. Which would you say are the best OLED tvs for single-player gaming? I dont play competitive so super high Hz doesn't matter to me. I mostly play RPG, Single player story, action games.

For that id lean Samsung because of game motion plus, if your not familiar with it i have a few videos on it I think its the perfect combo with these types of games. 42 or 48 s90f but if you’re budget is strict go 48 lg b5
​@TechWithKGThanks for the reply. What about the LG C5? How does it compare to the S90F for single player story games?
​@VectorAlphaSecgo with the C5, Samsung doesn't have proper HGIG and its game mode is wild (not in a good way).
So for a 65-inch TV, give me your top two for middle-of-the-road and then the next step up.

I wonder if the extra $100 is worth it for the Bravia 8 vs Bravia XR8B. The only meaningful difference I found was some contrast booster on the Bravia 8, but I haven't found any info on how useful it is.

Virtually no difference really, just the BRAVIA Core credits. Contrast booster appears to just be the rating Sony uses in their marketing it seems like its just a designation of the backlight technology in combination with how bright the panel can get.

@TechWithKG I just wish there was more info out there, like a side-by-side comparison, to know if it makes a difference. If it increases the brightness a little then probably worth it, but I have a hunch that I wouldn’t be able to tell the difference in a comparison which makes me want to save the $100.
Thank you KG

G4 and G5 better choice

@christianmarmol3230not true at all. the sony won tv of the year back to back years.  the processing clears LG.
It’s still beautiful. My friend just bought one and it’s still great. I have a G5, B8II, and S95F.  The A95L still competes in my opinion
Not worth it you can get the 77" S90F for half.

I grabbed a 83” C5 over an 83” G4 because of a variety of factors & findings.

Only fear now is if I’m going to miss out on picture (pop) dimensionality, but reviews have shown that the C5 is actually super close to G5 in real world brightness & processing, and bests it in color volume.

I feel better after Brian (Tech Therapy) talked me off of a fomo cliff.
I would have took the G4 instead
Interesting what is your findings that concluded you to get the C5?
I'm getting the G5 or G6 at 65 for my bedroom. Already got the G4 83in and it's freaking great !
Best decision!!! You won't regret it! I love my G5 55' for PC gaming! Damn it's nice 🤩👍
​@Serandi1987ya I bet. I've seen it in person a bunch of times but price was too high at 83in
77 CX vs 77C5/S90F for UHD movies a worthwhile difference in brightness/tone mapping/color or would you need a G5/S95F? What about a 77CX vs 83C5?

Depends on the price and room. I have a 48 inch C1, and I’m planning on upgrading this year to a 65 inch s90f for only $1400-$1250. I doubt you need the g5 or s95f if you are fine with a CX. I’d reccomend the s90f, especially in a brighter room.

S90F yes would be an upgrade because it is QD-OLED a superior technology over regular W-OLED. C5 will be brighter than your CX as well but the color won't be upgraded like it will with the S90F. IMO I wouldn't go 83 C5 id just save and get a 83 B5, the difference won't be that big unless you need the extra brightness.

Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.
98” is plenty and waaaaaaaaaaaayy cheaper. I saw the TCL QM6K at Costco for 1600 yesterday. Hell of a deal and value
It'll be $299 at Costco next year.  😅
Looks amazing but It already took a lot for me to spend 4k on a tv (s95d) but that’s the price of a new car😅
Yeah, the price is pretty wild, lol. The S95D is a NICE TV. You have a good setup for sure.
Bigger is better but there is such a thing as too expensive 😭

The fact we can get a 50” 4K TV for so cheap now compared to ten years ago should give you hope. TVs are one of the biggest examples of tech getting cheaper because they’re pretty straightforward. You can’t pack it with tons of new tech to keep it expensive and increasing in price like phones.
​@ThisIsTechTodayagreed! I was just making a joke of the $27k price tag.

Bigger is Better, I like it.
But, this is only for people who have money💰like that?!
I would gladly come over for a visit to watch sports and/or movies from time to time.
It’s cheap for 26k 😂 work stations go for 30-100k
That’s one way to put it. Haha

I had it running next to my G5 for two days just playing around with it. It’s amazing. At night with the lights off it is super bright and beautiful. Yes I can see the difference between my G5 and the B5 but honestly, it’s a great TV
Nice, yeah B5 gets overlooked but it’s honestly more than enough TV for most people.

I used to specialize in WiFi and the entire idea of making your primary connection over 6 is insane. People are going to by this is places like NYC where the RF spectrum is constantly screaming and will get awful performance.
Oh! Hey lexi!

to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.
@TheLexikitty oh hey! nice to see you around :)
RIGHT!!! It’s crazy to me, and they could’ve done this TV over some sort of Ethernet and maybe even POE+++ if it’s efficient enough

Why would 6ghz be worse for RF interference? Is there something else using that range in the USA or something? Here in the UK it's much easier to find clear channels in 6ghz. Majority of people will use the ISP supplied router which wont be Wi-Fi 6e or 7 capable. We recently tested 6ghz in a large city and we couldn't see any other 6ghz radios except our own broadcasting.

Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.

I used to specialize in WiFi and the entire idea of making your primary connection over 6 is insane. People are going to by this is places like NYC where the RF spectrum is constantly screaming and will get awful performance.
Oh! Hey lexi!

to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.
@TheLexikitty oh hey! nice to see you around :)
RIGHT!!! It’s crazy to me, and they could’ve done this TV over some sort of Ethernet and maybe even POE+++ if it’s efficient enough

Why would 6ghz be worse for RF interference? Is there something else using that range in the USA or something? Here in the UK it's much easier to find clear channels in 6ghz. Majority of people will use the ISP supplied router which wont be Wi-Fi 6e or 7 capable. We recently tested 6ghz in a large city and we couldn't see any other 6ghz radios except our own broadcasting.

As an owner of 3 Frame TVs (Non-Pro's from 2020 and 2022) due to the desire of "TVs that don't look like TVs". Everything Quinn said in this is true. The "art mode" is NEVER consistent in turning on or off correctly after turning off connected devices. Software is dog-slow and Samsung is adamant on trying to make sure you pay for their art subscription for features that should be STANDARD on a TV focused on letting you display art at a premium price tag. The mounting method changed in 2022 I think? the original mount was at least long enough to get one screw onto a stud, but the new mount sucks. If I were to say anything positive, it's that it can be confused for art sometimes, and it definitely makes a room feel a little nicer. Idk if I'd ever pay for the "Pro" version though. Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.

I used to specialize in WiFi and the entire idea of making your primary connection over 6 is insane. People are going to by this is places like NYC where the RF spectrum is constantly screaming and will get awful performance.
Oh! Hey lexi!

to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.
@TheLexikitty oh hey! nice to see you around :)
RIGHT!!! It’s crazy to me, and they could’ve done this TV over some sort of Ethernet and maybe even POE+++ if it’s efficient enough

Why would 6ghz be worse for RF interference? Is there something else using that range in the USA or something? Here in the UK it's much easier to find clear channels in 6ghz. Majority of people will use the ISP supplied router which wont be Wi-Fi 6e or 7 capable. We recently tested 6ghz in a large city and we couldn't see any other 6ghz radios except our own broadcasting.

Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.

I used to specialize in WiFi and the entire idea of making your primary connection over 6 is insane. People are going to by this is places like NYC where the RF spectrum is constantly screaming and will get awful performance.
Oh! Hey lexi!

to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.
@TheLexikitty oh hey! nice to see you around :)
RIGHT!!! It’s crazy to me, and they could’ve done this TV over some sort of Ethernet and maybe even POE+++ if it’s efficient enough

Why would 6ghz be worse for RF interference? Is there something else using that range in the USA or something? Here in the UK it's much easier to find clear channels in 6ghz. Majority of people will use the ISP supplied router which wont be Wi-Fi 6e or 7 capable. We recently tested 6ghz in a large city and we couldn't see any other 6ghz radios except our own broadcasting.

Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.

I used to specialize in WiFi and the entire idea of making your primary connection over 6 is insane. People are going to by this is places like NYC where the RF spectrum is constantly screaming and will get awful performance.
Oh! Hey lexi!

to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.
@TheLexikitty oh hey! nice to see you around :)
RIGHT!!! It’s crazy to me, and they could’ve done this TV over some sort of Ethernet and maybe even POE+++ if it’s efficient enough

Why would 6ghz be worse for RF interference? Is there something else using that range in the USA or something? Here in the UK it's much easier to find clear channels in 6ghz. Majority of people will use the ISP supplied router which wont be Wi-Fi 6e or 7 capable. We recently tested 6ghz in a large city and we couldn't see any other 6ghz radios except our own broadcasting.

Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.

I used to specialize in WiFi and the entire idea of making your primary connection over 6 is insane. People are going to by this is places like NYC where the RF spectrum is constantly screaming and will get awful performance.
Oh! Hey lexi!

to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.
@TheLexikitty oh hey! nice to see you around :)
RIGHT!!! It’s crazy to me, and they could’ve done this TV over some sort of Ethernet and maybe even POE+++ if it’s efficient enough

Why would 6ghz be worse for RF interference? Is there something else using that range in the USA or something? Here in the UK it's much easier to find clear channels in 6ghz. Majority of people will use the ISP supplied router which wont be Wi-Fi 6e or 7 capable. We recently tested 6ghz in a large city and we couldn't see any other 6ghz radios except our own broadcasting.

77 CX vs 77C5/S90F for UHD movies a worthwhile difference in brightness/tone mapping/color or would you need a G5/S95F? What about a 77CX vs 83C5?

Depends on the price and room. I have a 48 inch C1, and I’m planning on upgrading this year to a 65 inch s90f for only $1400-$1250. I doubt you need the g5 or s95f if you are fine with a CX. I’d reccomend the s90f, especially in a brighter room.

S90F yes would be an upgrade because it is QD-OLED a superior technology over regular W-OLED. C5 will be brighter than your CX as well but the color won't be upgraded like it will with the S90F. IMO I wouldn't go 83 C5 id just save and get a 83 B5, the difference won't be that big unless you need the extra brightness.

Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.

I used to specialize in WiFi and the entire idea of making your primary connection over 6 is insane. People are going to by this is places like NYC where the RF spectrum is constantly screaming and will get awful performance.
Oh! Hey lexi!

to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.
@TheLexikitty oh hey! nice to see you around :)
RIGHT!!! It’s crazy to me, and they could’ve done this TV over some sort of Ethernet and maybe even POE+++ if it’s efficient enough

Why would 6ghz be worse for RF interference? Is there something else using that range in the USA or something? Here in the UK it's much easier to find clear channels in 6ghz. Majority of people will use the ISP supplied router which wont be Wi-Fi 6e or 7 capable. We recently tested 6ghz in a large city and we couldn't see any other 6ghz radios except our own broadcasting.

I used to specialize in WiFi and the entire idea of making your primary connection over 6 is insane. People are going to by this is places like NYC where the RF spectrum is constantly screaming and will get awful performance.
Oh! Hey lexi!

to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.
@TheLexikitty oh hey! nice to see you around :)
RIGHT!!! It’s crazy to me, and they could’ve done this TV over some sort of Ethernet and maybe even POE+++ if it’s efficient enough

Why would 6ghz be worse for RF interference? Is there something else using that range in the USA or something? Here in the UK it's much easier to find clear channels in 6ghz. Majority of people will use the ISP supplied router which wont be Wi-Fi 6e or 7 capable. We recently tested 6ghz in a large city and we couldn't see any other 6ghz radios except our own broadcasting.

Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.

Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.

I used to specialize in WiFi and the entire idea of making your primary connection over 6 is insane. People are going to by this is places like NYC where the RF spectrum is constantly screaming and will get awful performance.
Oh! Hey lexi!

to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.
@TheLexikitty oh hey! nice to see you around :)
RIGHT!!! It’s crazy to me, and they could’ve done this TV over some sort of Ethernet and maybe even POE+++ if it’s efficient enough

Why would 6ghz be worse for RF interference? Is there something else using that range in the USA or something? Here in the UK it's much easier to find clear channels in 6ghz. Majority of people will use the ISP supplied router which wont be Wi-Fi 6e or 7 capable. We recently tested 6ghz in a large city and we couldn't see any other 6ghz radios except our own broadcasting.

Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.

I used to specialize in WiFi and the entire idea of making your primary connection over 6 is insane. People are going to by this is places like NYC where the RF spectrum is constantly screaming and will get awful performance.
Oh! Hey lexi!

to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.
@TheLexikitty oh hey! nice to see you around :)
RIGHT!!! It’s crazy to me, and they could’ve done this TV over some sort of Ethernet and maybe even POE+++ if it’s efficient enough

Why would 6ghz be worse for RF interference? Is there something else using that range in the USA or something? Here in the UK it's much easier to find clear channels in 6ghz. Majority of people will use the ISP supplied router which wont be Wi-Fi 6e or 7 capable. We recently tested 6ghz in a large city and we couldn't see any other 6ghz radios except our own broadcasting.

I used to specialize in WiFi and the entire idea of making your primary connection over 6 is insane. People are going to by this is places like NYC where the RF spectrum is constantly screaming and will get awful performance.
Oh! Hey lexi!

to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.
@TheLexikitty oh hey! nice to see you around :)
RIGHT!!! It’s crazy to me, and they could’ve done this TV over some sort of Ethernet and maybe even POE+++ if it’s efficient enough

Why would 6ghz be worse for RF interference? Is there something else using that range in the USA or something? Here in the UK it's much easier to find clear channels in 6ghz. Majority of people will use the ISP supplied router which wont be Wi-Fi 6e or 7 capable. We recently tested 6ghz in a large city and we couldn't see any other 6ghz radios except our own broadcasting.

Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.

I used to specialize in WiFi and the entire idea of making your primary connection over 6 is insane. People are going to by this is places like NYC where the RF spectrum is constantly screaming and will get awful performance.
Oh! Hey lexi!

to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.
@TheLexikitty oh hey! nice to see you around :)
RIGHT!!! It’s crazy to me, and they could’ve done this TV over some sort of Ethernet and maybe even POE+++ if it’s efficient enough

Why would 6ghz be worse for RF interference? Is there something else using that range in the USA or something? Here in the UK it's much easier to find clear channels in 6ghz. Majority of people will use the ISP supplied router which wont be Wi-Fi 6e or 7 capable. We recently tested 6ghz in a large city and we couldn't see any other 6ghz radios except our own broadcasting.

Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.

I used to specialize in WiFi and the entire idea of making your primary connection over 6 is insane. People are going to by this is places like NYC where the RF spectrum is constantly screaming and will get awful performance.
Oh! Hey lexi!

to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.
@TheLexikitty oh hey! nice to see you around :)
RIGHT!!! It’s crazy to me, and they could’ve done this TV over some sort of Ethernet and maybe even POE+++ if it’s efficient enough

Why would 6ghz be worse for RF interference? Is there something else using that range in the USA or something? Here in the UK it's much easier to find clear channels in 6ghz. Majority of people will use the ISP supplied router which wont be Wi-Fi 6e or 7 capable. We recently tested 6ghz in a large city and we couldn't see any other 6ghz radios except our own broadcasting.

Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.

Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.

I used to specialize in WiFi and the entire idea of making your primary connection over 6 is insane. People are going to by this is places like NYC where the RF spectrum is constantly screaming and will get awful performance.
Oh! Hey lexi!

to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.
@TheLexikitty oh hey! nice to see you around :)
RIGHT!!! It’s crazy to me, and they could’ve done this TV over some sort of Ethernet and maybe even POE+++ if it’s efficient enough

Why would 6ghz be worse for RF interference? Is there something else using that range in the USA or something? Here in the UK it's much easier to find clear channels in 6ghz. Majority of people will use the ISP supplied router which wont be Wi-Fi 6e or 7 capable. We recently tested 6ghz in a large city and we couldn't see any other 6ghz radios except our own broadcasting.

I treated myself to a big screen TV in 2005. For $2500, I got a 50" DLP - specifically because I was capable of fixing it. It lasted me for 17 years.
Knowing that electronics prices are so volatile, I avoided looking at advertisements for a while. I did find out that 2 months later, the same TV was $500 less.
Fast forward a few years, I'm helping a friend of mine without a car get his new big screen home. I mentioned to the sales guy that I had a DLP TV, but hadn't seen any in a while. He said that he saw a couple in the dollar store around the corner 🥵 That jerk-off.

I am glad that I was able to repair my TV for so long, until parts ran out. I purchased the last colour wheel for the LG DLP TV line ever.
